text: Family Member: Right. Doctor: You know? We, we have a look now which is not a super early look but it still is within, you know, a few weeks of finishing. text: Family Member: If he thinks he has a hernia, would that show on the CT scan? Would that be appropriate to send to the doctor? Doctor: No, because, yeah, the hernia, you know, when you’re laying down it really has to be pretty bad for it to be seen laying down. It’s usually when you’re standing up or sitting that it comes out. A hernia just means you have a weak area of muscle and then you have your bowel spill out. Typically, it doesn’t bother you unless it gets stuck, you know. Patient: Okay. Family Member: He’s having a lot of pain shooting up. Patient: Just I have a problem with my groin Doctor: Yeah. Patient: because that’s another problem I’m having to get my doctor to maybe get that taken, Doctor: Yeah. Patient: but it don’t hurt walking Doctor: No. Patient: or doing anything so. Doctor: Yeah, so you’ve seen a surgeon specifically for the hernia?

text: Patient: Uh when we had back Monday night. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: We got out of the car, I mean I couldn’t… Doctor: You felt it? Patient: Well I couldn’t step on it. I couldn’t walk up the step normally. I had to take the right leg up and take the right because if I try to go with this it’s just. Doctor: What’d you do in Alabama? Patient: Oh, tailgate with my college football friends. It was homecoming. Doctor: Okay, you’re making me work hard Mr. S____. You know what we have to do? We have to repeat your scans anyways because it’s time. You’re last one was July. Patient: My what scan? Doctor: Your CAT scan/bone scan just to see what’s going on. I’m not sure that the leg’s anything. You know, sometimes it’s a red herring like hey, I’ve been driving and I was partying and then it kind of hurt. We’re always perpetually paranoid about clots. You know that. Any type of blood clot. But I don’t think you have that because normally it shows up in our lower legs and our calves and your calves are as skinny as they come so and they don’t hurt and they’re not swollen so we’ll leave it there. But that leg, you know, we always have to fuss about because we know your bone scan can change at any time. I know we finished chemo but it might be time to figure out what else is happening. You look great so I’m thrilled about that but I also don’t want to just rely on the PSA and whatever to see what’s happening so CAT scan, chest, abdomen, and pelvis. Patient: Same thing I had before. Doctor: And bone scan, same thing. Now, let’s fast forward so we don’t freak out that if it’s worse, and you know my definition of worse is not the stuff went away that’s back, it’s just do I see more things or black spots on your bone scan. Your bone scan doesn’t changed much as you know. It kind of looks perpetually icky based on your original so you haven’t changed this whole time. I’m looking to see if there’s new spots in the leg or anywhere else. Now that I know you have pain and discomfort there, I of course look there to make sure there is nothing new there. Patient: Well, this only started when I…

text: Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer. Patient: That, that’s, okay. Doctor: Uh, the, uh, the idea of those drugs. It depends on which of the drugs. There’s a bunch of different HIV drugs. I can’t remember which one you mentioned. Patient: Um hum. text: Patient: Okay. But – Doctor: So, that makes it twenty-five percent. Patient: If they are negative ---- Doctor: If they’re negative, they’re negative. Patient: It’s over. Doctor: It’s over. Patient: Are they, did E_ --- Doctor: And, then, you know, I would say your brother who has prostate cancer he probably should get tested because it’s, you know, it’s possible he has the same gene mutation, um, inherited because it is a risk factor. So, from the standpoint of your family, that’s my advice – they get tested. For you personally, what does it mean? (pause) Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve also been doing clinical studies in a weird way with giving men testosterone Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Family Member: It was very interesting. And we was laughing because- Doctor: What cities did you go to in South Africa? Did you visit any cities or-? Patient: We was all over the place. text: Family Member: No. I would still be doing the Germany thing, I just- Doctor: I mean I think we’ll do that uh you know really quickly if that’s what you wanted to do. So I can work on that this week. Patient: Yeah. I appreciate that. Doctor: To find out - I’ll also see what I can find out about this test I mentioned then. Patient: Oh for the marker? Doctor: Yeah. We’ll just give us some information about uh uh you know we’ve learned that folks who have that marker, the cancer tends to be way more aggressive in addition to being less sensitive a hormone treatment, there may also be a marker, a change in the cancer that’s made it more aggressive. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, at least on the preliminary data, it looks like patients that live that long, have that marker, but it’s the guess if you have that marker, we should be more aggressive about- Patient: Treatment? Doctor: Chemo. And probably be putzing around I don’t know hormone or something, maybe do something more like PSMA or something like that. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Or more aggressive immune therapy, those kind of things. Family Member: Can, can you draw blood today for that?

text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know then clearly me telling you you know what things are getting worse just come off this and go get… Patient: Yeah, that’s right. text: Patient: Right. Doctor: You know, the issue that you run the risk is if it does show up and we'll catch it early or you're aware of it and it pops up in your lung. Patient: Yes, that’s not good. Doctor: That's something that can be associated with pain or sudden death. Patient: Right. That's right. My sister in law died of that. Healthcare Professional: Oh, I’m so sorry. Doctor: Not blood? Patient: Not blood, no. That's all I know about it. I mean, I just know that it’s not a good thing. Healthcare Professional: Do you have a feeling about it? Do you have a preference? Would you prefer to stay on the blood thinner? Patient: I just think- I just renewed it. Healthcare Professional: Oh. Patient: So I think I'll stay the course and then we'll see what happens after that. Because I'm pretty good watching. If anything is swelling or if I’m having any pain. I'll be a little more vigilant now to go to the doctor whereas before I'm like.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
